Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: The impact of stratospheric ozone depletion/recovery on Antarctic Climate
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

A data analysis and modeling project seeks to quantify the changes acting on Antarctic climate over the coming century attributable to the recovery of stratospheric ozone. Anticipated as a consequence of the Montreal Protocol to reduce ozone depleting halocarbon emissions, the seasonal polar ozone holes are now showing signs of recovery. The current lack of a discernable global warming effect on much of the East Antarctic (EA) is thought to stem from stratospheric cooling in part brought about by successive annual ozone depletion events. A steepening of the polar vortex due to stratospheric cooling is accompanied by a strengthening of the westerly winds that circle the continent, which in turn lessens the meridional heat transfer from a warming Southern Hemisphere. As this stratospheric cooling is removed, a stronger warming of the EA is possible.
A range of current global climate model outputs will be examined as to their ability to reproduce recent Antarctic climate conditions. Whether these can be reliably attributed to a single factor such as ozone or other (well mixed) greenhouse gases may enable future Antarctic climate responses to be better estimated. Antarctic climate variability, especially with respect to surficial melt at the coastal margins has important potential impacts on ice sheet mass balance and global sea-level rise in the coming century.

Climate and environmental change over Antarctica and the Southern Ocean has far-reaching impacts through its ties to biogeochemical cycling, ocean circulation and global sea level rise.  The latter are highly relevant to society, and thus understanding the causes of Antarctic climate change is of paramount importance.  The work that we have done in this project has served to enhance scientific understanding of how Antarctic climate responds to stratospheric ozone depletion and recovery.  In particular, we have focused on ozone effects on the atmospheric circulation, sea ice and the atmospheric energy budget.

The latter are highly relevant to society, and thus understanding the causes of Antarctic climate change is of paramount importance. The work that we have done in this project has served to enhance scientific understanding of how Antarctic climate responds to stratospheric ozone depletion and recovery. In particular, we have focused on ozone effects on the atmospheric circulation, sea ice and the atmospheric energy budget. Normal 0 false false false MicrosoftInternetExplorer4 Our results suggest that the effects of stratospheric ozone recovery on the Southern Hemisphere atmospheric circulation will nearly cancel the effects of increasing greenhouse gases during the next half-century, resulting in minimal forced circulation changes in austral summer. We similarly found a large impact of ozone recovery on future Antarctic sea ice trends, with ozone effects mitigating a significant fraction of the projected sea ice loss due to rising greenhouse gases. In contrast, ozone depletion during the past few decades was shown to not explain the observed sea ice changes over this time period, with internal climate variability being a more likely candidate. Finally, significant impacts of ozone depletion and recovery on the Antarctic atmospheric energy budget were identified in state-of-the-art climate model simulations. In particular, ozone forcing was shown to drive large trends in the net incoming top-of-atmosphere radiation over the Antarctic, which were compensated by opposite-signed trends in the horizontal convergence of the atmospheric energy transport. A similar compensation was found in both models and observations in association with (unforced) interannual variability, and with regard to the climatological mean energy budget. Normal 0 false false false MicrosoftInternetExplorer4 In summary, the results from this project will serve to enhance our ability to interpret past observed Antarctic changes, and will lead to more informed projections of the changes yet to come.
